1.text: Cosmology and Cosmic Order in Islamic Astronomy Robert G. Morrison * Bowdoin College rgmorris@bowdoin.edu Abstract This article analyzes how the astronomy of Islamic societies in the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries can be understood as cosmological. By studying the Arabic translations  ofthe  relevant  Greek  terms  and  then  the  definitions  ofthe  medieval  Arabic dictionaries, the article finds that Arabic terms did not communicate order in the way implied by the Greek ho kósmos (/uni1F41 κόσμος; the cosmos). Yet, astronomers of the period sometimes discussed cosmic order in addition to describing the cosmos. This article finds, too, that a new technical term, nafs al-amr (the fact of the matter) became part of later discussions of cosmic order. Keywords cosmology - cosmography - astronomy /uni02BFilm al-kalām -nafs al-amr - Ṣadr al-Sharī/uni02BFa al-Bukhārī - al-Sayyid al-Sharīf al-Jurjānī - Mu'ayyad al-Dīn al-/uni02BFUrḍī Defining Islamic cosmology, the cosmology of Islamic societies, is not simple because cosmology does not have historic equivalents in languages such as Arabic, Persian, or Ottoman Turkish, and does not map onto a single actors' category. Cosmology has been applied to synthesize a wide variety of sub-fields within Islamic studies, ranging, on the one hand, from the synthesis of a number of scientific approaches to the universe, and on the other hand, to the description of the world views of ṣūfī s to the outlooks implicit in certain social structures.$^{1} Survey articles capture this range in various ways. Thus, most of hayʾa turns out to be cosmography, but there are cases in which authors talk about the universe's underlying order, and this article aims to clarify which is which and why. Within the history of /uni02BFilm al-hayʾa , the article focuses on writers associated with the Marāgha Observatory through 1400. Academic discussions of Islamic cosmology in all periods have been complicated by the wide semantic range of the Greek ho kósmos (cosmos), by how the Arabic words /uni02BFālam (world) and niẓām (order) render more than one Greek term respectively, and by how neither Arabic lexicographic dictionaries nor texts translated from the Greek make a necessary connection between /uni02BFālam and niẓām .  Acknowledging the range of possible uses and definitions of Arabic words like /uni02BFālam and English words like 'cosmos' is important background for the debates about cosmic order that follow. Thus, the article begins by examining the semantic range of kósmos in Greek and how that and related words were translated into Arabic. These lexicographic considerations matter because they clarify why thirteenth and fourteenth-century discussions of the cosmos may or may not communicate an inherent order. These different stances on whether the cosmos was inherently ordered are the focus of the first part of the article. Second, the paper will examine the ways in which some writers on /uni02BFilm  al-hayʾa ,  particularly Mu'ayyad al-Dīn al/uni02BFUrḍī (d. 1266), discussed /uni02BFilm al-hayʾa 's models in terms of the cosmos' underlying order. As earlier scholarship has suggested, /uni02BFUrḍī's position could have developed out of a conversation or debate with kalām .$^{1}$^{1}  Third, following /uni02BFUrḍī, the article engages the astronomy of Quṭb al-Dīn al-Shīrāzī (d. 1311), which featured increased confidence about the correctness of astronomy's models but fewer references to an ordered cosmos. Fourth, the paper, as an interlude, will mention Ṣadr al-Sharī/uni02BFa's (d. 1347) position about how the knowledge afforded by /uni02BFilm al-hayʾa was restricted to particulars and did not lead to knowledge of an essential natural order. Ṣadr al-Sharī/uni02BFa's response to Shīrāzī and Naṣīr al-Dīn al-Ṭūsī's theoretical astronomy illustrates how one could be an influential writer on /uni02BFilm al-hayʾa without arguing that there was an underlying natural order detectable through the systematic interrogation of creation. Specifically, the technical term nafs al-amr (the fact of the matter) became relevant to discussions of cosmic order. 1 Introduction: The Greek Semantic Background and the Semantic Range of the Arabic Translations The wide variety of the ways in which the word kósmos , which informs Western understandings of cosmology, was used in ancient Greek and the different semantic ranges of the Arabic translations of the relevant Greek terms complicate the task of specifying how /uni02BFilm al-hayʾa was (or was not) cosmological. The semantic range of the word /uni02BFālam , often used as a translation for kósmos , does not include all of the ways in which kósmos was used in ancient Greek, but adds some others, as is acknowledged in the Encyclopaedia of Islam, Second Edition article '/uni02BF Ālam.' Likewise, there are Arabic texts that address seemingly cosmological  matters,  such  as  the  Arabic  treatise Fī  Mabādi'  al-kull ,  which Charles Genequand translated as On the Cosmos , even though the world kósmos was probably not in the title of Alexander of Aphrodisias' Greek original upon which the Arabic text was based.$^{1}$^{2} Still, Fī Mabādi' al-kull was dedicated to a holistic view of the cosmos, the question of cosmic order, as well as that order's  moral  implications.  Likewise,  Aristotle's De  Caelo had  much  to  say about the cosmos, but was also concerned with more than cosmography, i.e., with more than just the physical models that accounted for and predicted observable  celestial  motions.$^{1}$^{3}  Reviewing  the  semantic  range  ofthe  relevant Greek terms and how they passed into Arabic lends insights into why a writer in English might classify all of these topics as cosmology, and why different writers in Islamic societies wrote about the cosmos in different ways. The semantic range of the Greek kósmos affected the semantic range of the analytic term 'cosmology' in European languages. Of less significance for this article, kósmos also denoted ornamentation,$^{2}$^{2} and by metaphorical extension, honor and credit as well as the words for six and ten in the Theologoumena Arithmeticae .$^{2}$^{3} The wide semantic range of the Greek word kósmos helps account for the wide range of ways in which cosmology has been defined within Islamic studies. The examples from Aristotle and Plato entailed cosmic order; the example from Ptolemy's Planetary Hypotheses did not. Also important for this article's focus on discussions of cosmic order in /uni02BFilm al-hayʾa texts are cases in which the cosmos is thought to be ordered, but a different word hḗ táxis (/uni1F25 τᾰ ́ ξ/uni1FD0ς) is used for the order of the cosmos itself; consider De Caelo 280a: 'For it is clear that when the elements come together, the resulting order ( táxis ) is not fortuitous, but always the same, especially in the words of the authors of this view, since they attribute each arrangement to one of a pair of opposites. If then the whole sum of a body, being a continuum, is disposed and ordered now in this way and now in that, and the formation of this whole is a world ( kósmos ), then it will not be the world ( kósmos ) which comes into being and perishes, but its dispositions only.' These passages from De Caelo and the Timaeus (in the previous paragraph) relate the cosmos' order to cosmogony. This section of the article has shown that the distinction between the cosmos and order emerged, to an extent, from the translation of Greek terms into Arabic. As even more of the distinction is due to meanings that have accrued to certain terminology in the intervening centuries of history, we should be attentive when applying analytic terms derived from Greek to post-classical science in Islamic societies. 2 Cosmic Order in Muʾayyad al-Dīn al-/uni02BFUrḍī's Astronomy Aristotle and Plato linked the order of the cosmos to cosmogony. Because cosmogony was not a topic of /uni02BFilm al-hayʾa , the question of certainty about cosmic order lurked beneath the surface. Of all the /uni02BFilm al-hayʾa texts that this article examines,  Muʾayyad  al-Dīn  al-/uni02BFUrḍī's  (d.  1266) Kitāb  al-Hayʾa (The  Book  of Hayʾa ) featured the greatest concern with epistemological questions, particularly the extent to which one could be certain of one's theories.$^{4}$^{1} Epistemological concerns shaped his argument about why the most perfect motion was a  circular  ( dawriyya )  motion, and of all the things that move circularly, the sphere ( al-kura ) was the most fluid ( aslas ) of all.$^{4}$^{2} T o /uni02BFUrḍī, because circular motion was the simplest motion and because the sphere was the solid each part of which best resembled the rest, it was most likely ( bi-l-ḥarī )  that  the heavens were composed of spheres. Later in Kitāb al-Hayʾa , /uni02BFUrḍī briefly considered Ptolemy's conclusion, in the Planetary Hypotheses ,  that  many of the orbs could be replaced by tori or truncated orbs ( manshūrāt ).$^{4}$^{3}  /uni02BFUrḍī  explained that the torus (or truncated orb) was one of many 'spherical bodies like rings and they had neither poles nor axes'; he wondered, then, 'according to what thing is their impetus ( i/uni02BFtimād ) in motion?' 12.text: heavenly  bodies.'  /uni02BFUrḍī's  argument  for  orbs  against  manshūrāt  was  cosmographic because it focused on the external characteristics of the celestial bodies. Implicit in /uni02BFUrḍī's argument that spheres (and not manshūrāt) were most appropriate and most likely, was an acknowledgement that a preference for spheres (or orbs) could not be decisively substantiated and was, therefore, not certain. Such a qualification was absent from everything that /uni02BFUrḍī said about cosmic order. /uni02BFUrḍī's  conviction  that  the  heavens  were  ordered,  and  that /uni02BFilm  al-hayʾa 's models should reflect that order, emerged in a statement about what earlier practitioners of astronomy had found: 'The essence ( faḥwā ) of their words is their firm belief ( i/uni02BFtiqāduhum ) that the order ( niẓām ) of these motions is accomplished through spheres, with the centers of the mobiles moving through their motion on the circumferences of circles imagined in these spheres moving about their centers with uniform, continual, and continuous motions in an order and arrangement with no disruption in it.'$^{4}$^{4} Motions found their order in uniformity. Even with models comprised of tori, the order would exist nonetheless. Thus, a significant shortcoming of Ptolemy's models was cosmological, because Ptolemy's models did not reflect or explain cosmic order: 'Conceiving the likes of this and its obscurities is from among the likes of that which is not hidden from he who has the least discernment that it is contrary ( mujānib ) to the  settled  principles  ( uṣūl )  ofthis  science,  and  unsuitable  for  the  ordered state  ( ḥāla muntaẓama )  and  the  continuous  affair  ( al-amr al-mustamirr )  in which there are no shortcomings or deficiencies.'$^{4}$^{5} /uni02BFUrḍī's  premise  that  the goal of hayʾa was to explain celestial motions in terms of the cosmos' order, was one respect in which Ptolemy fell short. Just before /uni02BFUrḍī began his chapter on his own model for the upper planets and Venus, he commented that 'all of what he [Ptolemy] said about these things, even if it is improbable ( mustab/uni02BFada ) in the beginning, it has approaches to hayʾa that can be rectified in a way different from that specified in the Almagest ,  and in addition to what he mentioned  in  the Planetary Hypotheses (al-Iqtiṣāṣ),  through  which  this  winding [ iltifāf (a type of motion in latitude)] can be accomplished and it can proceed according to order ( niẓām ) and arrangement ( tartīb ).'$^{4}$^{6} Conformity to cosmic order was the standard that led /uni02BFUrḍī to conclude that his models were better than Ptolemy's even if /uni02BFUrḍī could not be certain that his models offered accurate representations of external reality. 44 Ibid., 28. 45 Ibid., 115. /uni02BFUrḍī has used uṣūl to mean something other than the building-blocks of models, since /uni02BFUrḍī's models contain different building blocks than those of Ptolemy. 46 Ibid., 192.

13.text: Although  Ptolemy's  models  did  explain  the  limited  observable  motions, /uni02BFUrḍī  claimed that his way ( ṭarīqunā ) more closely resembles the state of affairs suitable for the heavens.$^{4}$^{7} He concluded the section of Kitāb al-hayʾa , in which he presented his own model for the upper planets and Venus, by commenting: 'In this way, we have corrected the motions of these planets and their matters have been ordered ( wa-intaẓama amruhā ) according to the depiction suitable for the heavenly nature ( al-ṭabī/uni02BFa  al-samāwiyya ).'$^{4}$^{8}  The  only  uncertainty that /uni02BFUrḍī harbored was with respect to the external reality of his own models, not about the existence of a natural order that the models should reflect. A cosmos of ordered motions was an ordered cosmos. The criterion of simplicity, which /uni02BFUrḍī also invoked at times, functioned in a way similar to cosmic order. /uni02BFUrḍī began Kitāb al-Hayʾa by presenting a list of foundations that earlier astronomers had established, often drawing on the conclusions of philosophy: for instance, the idea that the heavens were spherical and the heavens' motions were circular;$^{4}$^{9} or that the earth was spherical and stationary.$^{5}$^{0} Probably the most important of these ideas was that whereby the heavens were seen as comprised of spheres or spherical bodies that revolved uniformly about their own centers. Later in the text, in a critique of Ptolemy's lunar model, /uni02BFUrḍī  said  that  some  ofthese  principles  ( uṣūl )  were taken over from other areas, while others were a priori ( badīhiyya ).$^{5}$^{1}  Conformity to observations and to the adopted principles was evidence for a model's external  reality.$^{5}$^{2}  The  simplest  model  that  met  those  criteria  would  be  the best.$^{5}$^{3} Like cosmic order, the criterion of simplicity stood apart from the foundational principles ( uṣūl ) of /uni02BFUrḍī's models. At the end of the section on the lunar model, /uni02BFUrḍī pointed out that the cosmic order that his models reflected was qualitative, and that the understanding of this cosmic order transcended the definition of mathematical astronomy: Ifit  has  been demonstrated through these observations and principles that Ptolemy used, and which were also precisely what we used, that that which is observed from the states of the moon corresponds to that which emerges  through  calculation,  then  it  is  not  hidden  from  any  rational 47 Ibid., 229. 48 Ibid., 230-231. 49 Ibid., 34. 50 On the earth's sphericity, see Ibid., 38. For /uni02BFUrḍī, the value of models that reflected cosmological considerations of order and simplicity was qualitative and not quantitative, as there was no way to confirm these models' external reality through observations,  and  the  preferred  models  offered  no  additional  application. 17.text: among the writers on /uni02BFilm al-hayʾa was whether and how to explain and communicate the underlying order of the cosmos, the external aspects of which they all examined. Hayʾa was always cosmography, along with occasional cosmological excursuses. Shīrāzī, for his part, was confident about the external reality of his models, but did not reflect explicitly on cosmic order as much as /uni02BFUrḍī had. Still,  Shīrāzī  introduced into hayʾa texts  a  new epistemological term, nafs al-amr (the fact of the matter), that arose also in subsequent astronomers' discussions  ofcosmic  order.$^{6}$^{6}  The Tuḥfa 's  chapter  on uṣūl (here:  hypotheses/ building  blocks  ofmodels)  communicated  that  astronomers'  models  were more  than  explanations  ofthe  particular  astronomical  observations  made. The chapter began: On the ascription of apparently irregular motions known through observation to hypotheses that entail [the motions'] uniformity in the fact of the matter ( fī nafs al-amr ), but their variation with respect to us; for irregular motion does not result from the heavenly bodies.$^{6}$^{7} The uṣūl that Shīrāzī listed were true because they explained the anomalous motions observed in terms of motions of orbs that were uniform (i.e., ordered) in the fact of the matter. The phenomenon of retrograde motion, which the hypotheses ordered, was also a locus for another rare reference in the Tuḥfa to order: '[retrogradation] is as in the wandering planets and they are so named because unordered ( ghayr muntaẓama ) motions arise from them, just as walking, stopping, and returning arise from one who is confused.'$^{6}$^{8} The use of the phrase fī nafs al-amr indicates that the way in which Shīrāzī became certain of the hypotheses' existence had changed. Shīrāzī (and others) used the phrase 'in the fact of the matter' to assert that things could exist in the fact of the matter ( fī nafs al-amr ) without necessarily existing externally.$^{6}$^{9} That the term was more than just a turn of phrase is demonstrated by the fact that al-Sayyid al-Sharīf al-Jurjānī (d. 1413) and Ṭūsī, among others, wrote independent treatises defining the term, though the historical 66 Ibn  Kammūna  used nafs  al-amr with  respect  to  astronomy;  see  Langermann,  'Ibn Kammūna,' 292. 18.text: actors disagreed about what the term meant, and Shīrāzī did not provide his own definition.$^{7}$^{0} Ṭūsī defined nafs al-amr as the active (or universal) intellect, while Jurjānī understood something to be true in nafs al-amr when it was a true statement whether or not the subject of that statement existed externally.$^{7}$^{1} Nafs al-amr was a mode of existence and/or a way of knowing. Shīrāzī's assertions that the hypotheses ordered the observations, but in the fact of the matter and not necessarily externally, could be interpreted as a   development of /uni02BFUrḍī's relative confidence that models should reflect cosmic order as well as his acknowledgement that the models he proposed might not have an external reality.  While  Shīrāzī's Tuḥfa lacked  the  cosmological  comments  found  in /uni02BFUrḍī's Kitāb al-Hayʾa , Shīrāzī's use of the term nafs al-amr entailed some perception of cosmic order, even if that order did not exist   externally. 4 Ṣadr al-Sharī/uni02BFa al-Bukhārī's Denial of an Order Inherent in the Cosmos Shīrāzī's use of nafs al-amr also makes sense in the context of the work of another astronomer, Ṣadr al-Sharī/uni02BFa  al-Bukhārī  (d.  1347),  and  his  different  perspective on the epistemological status of hayʾa 's  models and on the type of knowledge afforded by hayʾa . In a study of the astronomer, Ahmad Dallal found that Ṣadr al-Sharī/uni02BFa held that astronomy could not attain knowledge (and, thus, understanding) of general principles, but, instead, only knowledge of the particular motions. Ṣadr al-Sharī/uni02BFa's astronomy discussed neither an underlying cosmic order that existed externally, as we saw in /uni02BFUrḍī's work, nor a cosmic order connected to nafs al-amr .  His  work  on  astronomy  was  purely  cosmographic. He wrote that, 'the science of astronomy is the science (dealing with) the upper (celestial) bodies together with the four lower ones with respect to their  configurations,  quantities,  positions,  and  motions  that  are  intrinsic  to them. This fundamental order was due to God's role as creator. 6 Conclusion While earlier research on Islamic cosmology recognized and studied scientific cosmologies, this article has shown that even a single discipline ( /uni02BFilm al-hayʾa ) over a couple of centuries contained cosmology, in the form of cosmography and in the form of discussions of cosmic order. In the fifth section of this paper, I have shown that the emergence of the term nafs al-amr meant that cosmic order  remained  relevant  even  if /uni02BFilm  al-hayʾa texts,  beginning  with  Shīrāzī's Nihāya , started to reconsider that discipline's relationship to the philosophy of Plato and Aristotle as well as whether something could be real without existing externally. While academic studies of cosmology are framed by the semantic range of the Greek kósmos ,  the historical actors' own views were affected by the ways in which the relevant Greek terms were translated and appropriated. In  particular,  the  Arabic /uni02BFālam translated  more  than  just  the  Greek kósmos , and,  over  the  centuries,  a  distinction  emerged  between  the  cosmos,  which came to be thought of more as creation, and cosmic order.
